Should we do Stem cell research?
AKonsen

If you're talking about human embryonic stem cell research, then my answer is "no." I've researched the issue exhaustively, and it's clearly illegal (if federally funded), immoral, and scientifically unnecessary.
 
 If you're talking about research on human adult stem cells or stem cells from animals, then I say "have at it."

 Personally, I think stem cell research will be a long and expensive dead end. 
 I do not believe that we should even have stem cells. Even though their growth into an adult human has been ruined, they should all be destroyed. However, scientists in Europe have them, and our scientists are so eager to get ahead.
 Yet, I cannot help but actually laugh over the whole issue. We have available to us billions of new stem cells each year that would not require using and embryo or human bone marrow (which has limited stem cell research usage, I’ve heard). After a baby is born, we cut the umbilical cord and get rid of it and the placenta. Its examined and thrown away. Scientists are screaming for more lines of stem cells and yet they have a whole ton of them to experiment on without causing any moral dilemma. Why don't they use those cord blood stem cells to research on instead? If only a few people actually freeze their children’s cord in case they need to use it later, why can't scientists experiment on all the ones that are thrown away?

 Yes, we should have it. The benefits are enormous. Even though fetal stem cells are the most choice I don't think that women should be paid have abortions just to provide some. They should take the cells from either miscarred, or already aborted fetuses and clone the cells for more when needed.

 there is no logical reason not to be an organ donor, likewise, if a woman has already chosen to terminate her pregnancy, there is no logical reason why that choice could not be used to try to benefit another. This would be one form of compassion.

 due respect, you handle mild ridicule admirably... :)
 
 however, you do seem to advocate abortion, as well as impregnation for the purpose of fetal donation.
 
 basically, granting abortion for the purpose of stem research is equal to exploiting a human being for the sake of other humans. this can arguably be ethically wrong or right, but the issue is that a life is killed for this type of stem research to take place.

there is no logical reason not to be an organ donor, likewise, if a woman has already chosen to terminate her pregnancy, there is no logical reason why that choice could not be used to try to benefit another. This would be one form of compassion

If you're talking about human embryonic stem cell research, then my answer is "no." I've researched the issue exhaustively, and it's clearly illegal (if federally funded), immoral, and scientifically unnecessary.
 
 If you're talking about research on human adult stem cells or stem cells from animals, then I say "have at it."

 
 Absolute garbage. The typical regressive argument founded on nothing but religious dogma, and without any consideration for healing human suffering.
 
 The entire thing should be and will be tossed in the trash, where it belongs, when Bush and his extremist followers are out! 
 
 There's absolutely nothing immoral, nor wrong stem cell research. What is immoral are the laws that limit the research, as the current backward irrational religious based laws do.
 
 Why stem cell research is in an abortion Forum is beyond me. It's a Scinece topic, if there ever was one, and has nothing to do with abortion except in the mind of the most backwards extremist minds in the entire World.
 
 Stem cell research will happen, in full, and not be limmited by the absurd laws created by the pope's extremists. It's only a matter of time, before all those ridiculous laws are undone and trashed.

Yes we should do this research.
Tastyfish

I'm for it, but not in the US so less of an issue for me doing a biotech degree
 There is a difference between these and adult stem cells, most cells have limits on how often they can reproduce and the adult undiffereniated cells can usually only replicate a few times, nowhere near enough to grow an organ, whether imoratlising them helps I do not know, but this has more added complications. Other than the source of these cells how is this an issue at all, alowing abortion and not stem cell research seems bizarre and purely a political vote gathering thing.
Nallyo

I agree that this research has enormous implications in the regeneration of lost tissue. HOWEVER, as many have said, it should be taken from adults (I believe the liver and the base of the brain have an abundance of stem cells and regenerate them regularly) or from the umbilical cords of already born babies. If you get into "dead babies"/aborted fetuses, the legal issues become a lot more complicated and the moral battles will be endless. Stick to the stem cells that can be taken without any controversy and the research will go farther.
Tastyfish

There are complications with adult cells, they are more undifferentiated cells than the 'ideal' stem cells (i.e one that will grow into an organ) as there is anti cancer mechanisms that limit the number of times they can divide. Not sure if what the problem with umilical cord tissue is, or if there is one (though if it is part of the placenta rather the baby there may be- some genetic wierdness goes on here with DNA from specific sources (paternal DNA only or something similar, something unusual) being activated rather than going on normal equal expression)
 
 The research on feotal stem cells is primarily to find out what seperates them from normal cells and to find away to transform adult cells into the type of stem cells we want. 
 
 Still, as long as the abortions are going on for other reasons and this provides a large source of stem cells whcih would otherwise be burnt what's the problem, if abortion was illegal then fair enough that these stem cells wouldn't be used.
Nallyo

The problem some people see with getting them from abortions is that it will continue to provide a "market" for aborted fetuses, which will make it that much harder to make illegal. It's a whole moral debate that I believe could be avoided if stem cells from the umbilical cord, or as you pointed out, the placenta were used. I mean, how many people have a problem with those being used for scientific research?
Tastyfish

Only problem might be that they are not really that useful for the 'stem cell' research side of the research but arn't really sure.
 I really don't think anyone ever suggests production of stem cells for research is even a benefit of having abortion, let alone a possible reason (however much a small one) I would say it is entirely out of abortion debate (or at least really should be) and along the same lines as gun ownership providing practice for military doctors at treating gun shot wounds- clearly not a deciding factor for or against but just something that may as well happen if it is going on.
 
 Only time I can see there being a big conflict would be in the future once the technology has been sorted about halfway (can get the organs to grow but not normal cells to become stem cells) and parents creating an embryo (before any differentiation occurs- so it is just plain cells) to provide stem cells for a very badly physically disabled child (not sure whether rejection is that much of an issue, would imagine it is). But this is going to be a very unusual situation and hopefully won't occur due ot the order of breakthroughs made.
amycus

You advocate human embryonic stem cell research over other types of stem cell research?

 
 Stem cell research using embryonic cells is, so far, the easiest way for scientists to research the specialization code. Once they have figured out what biochemical code triggers the specialization process, then they can figure out the way to research adult cells. Until then, I am a supporter of human embryonic stem cell research. 
 
 If you look at it from a religious stand point, God put us in this world and gave us the ability to do all those things.

The reason this issue is so closely tied to the abortion debate is because it all comes down to one question: are the unborn human?
 
 If a fetus is human, then it darn well deserves protection. I myself wouldn't appreciate it much if someone killed me to do research, just because I wasn't developed enough yet to defend myself.
 
 If a fetus is not human, then go ahead and kill it.
 
 The same goes for abortion; the root question is all about whether the unborn deserve protection.

 The only issue right now is that federal money can't be used for some types of stem cell research. Private money can be used on any stem cell research.

 Remember too, dear Republicans, as you're so fond of pointing out the free-market economy, scientific research follows the same evolution. If we restrict it, instead of research growing in the US at least partially under our care, it will grow in other countries without such restrictions. Job loss, IP/patent loss, and we won't be the leaders in an emerging bio-tech. Not good for America.

 No one knows the limitations or potential for either embryonic or adult stem cells yet. Adult stem cells have about 10x the funding but it's still barely getting started. It is known that embryonic stem cells are more "flexible" in terms of differentiation, but really, no one yet knows. Way too soon to know things like that, even as a guess.

Adept

Here is an angle I'm struggling with..... Is it moral to use the medical results of the Nazi torture doctors? They did some barbaric tests on humans which resulted in some serious medical advancements.
 
 It boils down to this: Do the ends justify the means?
 
 What do you think?

 
 Well, will not using those results somehow make the behaviour of the Nazi's acceptable? No. Will it (potentially) enrich and save lives? Yes. 
 
 Seems like a pretty easy question to me.
 
 Do the ends justify the means? Of course. They are, after all, the only thing that ever can.
 
 I find that 'The end cannot justify the means' is a phrase often used without full consideration. In order to achieve certain goals, certain acts must be undertaken. More accurately, the phrase should be 'The end only justifies the requisite means'. For example, Giving someone a blast on the horn after they cut you off in traffic is justified. Shooting them is not. However, shooting someone is justified if it is in self defense, the defense of another, in times of war, state sanctioned executions, etc.
 
 So the ends don't justify any means at all, only the means that are required in order to achieve said ends.
 
 If any of that made any sense...

 I'm sitting here in Nashville, and honestly, this isn't a big issue. You may hear a couple of extremists, but that would be in any state. Nobody I know is upset about Frist.
 
 Most people don't even understand basic biology, much less the stem cell debate. To them, if Frist says it's cool, then it's cool. Also, most people can figure out the difference between coma and braindead. In a nutshell, one is asleep, dreaming.. and the other is dead, but we're keeping their body alive. No big.
